EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several vehicles were stuck in mud and flooded out. Additional urban flooding was reported elsewhere in the Inland Empire.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A moderate strength trough of low pressure swept through the SoCal Bight with gusty winds, mountain snow and heavy rainfall. Rainfall totals of 1-2 inches occurred over the coast and valleys, with isolated amounts of 6-8 inches along favored coastal slopes. Snowfall was 2 to 8 inches above 6,000 ft with up to 12 inches on the higher peaks. Wind caused major damage to the historic Bay Theater in San Diego. Around 10 swift water rescues were reported in the Inland Empire and San Bernardino County Mountains.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: CHP reported two large trees down along Sage Road.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A moderate strength trough of low pressure swept through the SoCal Bight with gusty winds, mountain snow and heavy rainfall. Rainfall totals of 1-2 inches occurred over the coast and valleys, with isolated amounts of 6-8 inches along favored coastal slopes. Snowfall was 2 to 8 inches above 6,000 ft with up to 12 inches on the higher peaks. Wind caused major damage to the historic Bay Theater in San Diego. Around 10 swift water rescues were reported in the Inland Empire and San Bernardino County Mountains.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A minor debris flow was reported along Green River Rd. in Corona. The flow was associated with the Canyon 1 Fire.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A moderate strength trough of low pressure swept through the SoCal Bight with gusty winds, mountain snow and heavy rainfall. Rainfall totals of 1-2 inches occurred over the coast and valleys, with isolated amounts of 6-8 inches along favored coastal slopes. Snowfall was 2 to 8 inches above 6,000 ft with up to 12 inches on the higher peaks. Wind caused major damage to the historic Bay Theater in San Diego. Around 10 swift water rescues were reported in the Inland Empire and San Bernardino County Mountains.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds gusted in the 60-74 mph range at Fremont Canyon. Other stations in the Santa Ana Mountains saw lighter winds, though Pleasants peak did have a peak gust of 65 mph.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A surface high built over the Great Basin, resulting in offshore pressure gradients and Santa Ana Winds in SoCal on the 27th, 28th and 29th of January. The east/west nature of the gradients favored San Diego County for the strongest winds. A peak wind gust of 89 mph was reported at Sill Hill.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The mesonet station in Fremont Canyon reported a brief period with wind gusts in excess of 70 mph. Pleasants Peak also gusted to 66 mph.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A surface high built over the Great Basin, resulting in offshore pressure gradients and Santa Ana Winds in SoCal on the 27th, 28th and 29th of January. The east/west nature of the gradients favored San Diego County for the strongest winds. A peak wind gust of 89 mph was reported at Sill Hill.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Highland Springs mesonet reported gusts in excess of 58 mph for 3 hours. Winds were significantly lower across the rest of the Inland Empire.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A surface high built over the Great Basin, resulting in offshore pressure gradients and Santa Ana Winds in SoCal on the 27th, 28th and 29th of January. The east/west nature of the gradients favored San Diego County for the strongest winds. A peak wind gust of 89 mph was reported at Sill Hill.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several inches of snow resulted in chain controls along portions of Highways 74 and 243.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A broad trough and weak Pacific cold front sweeped through the region late on the 2nd and into the 3rd. Rainfall was light with some impacts from snowfall in the mountains of Riverside and San Bernardino County.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple locations in the San Bernardino County Mountains reported 1-3 inches of snow. Snow Valley had the highest total with 4-8 inches of new snow reported on the morning of the 4th. Chain controls were needed along Highways 18 and 38.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A broad trough and weak Pacific cold front sweeped through the region late on the 2nd and into the 3rd. Rainfall was light with some impacts from snowfall in the mountains of Riverside and San Bernardino County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Gusts of over 60 mph reported at the Whitewater Mesonet station for about 12 hours.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak trough passed through the Pacific Northwest, bringing gusty winds to the desert slopes in Southern California from the 6th through the 7th. There were no significant impacts reported.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Palm Springs Airport ASOS reported a gust of 51 mph around 1800 PST on the 12th. Earlier that day, 4 planes were diverted from PSP due to wind shear on final approach. Numerous power outages were reported in Palm Springs, as well as downed trees and power lines.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak trough from the Pacific Northwest progressed through Southern California on the 11th and 12th, bringing gusty winds to the Coachella Valley, San Bernardino County Mountains, and San Diego County Deserts. Palm Springs Airport diverted 4 planes early on the 12th due to wind shear on final approach. The opening of the Coachella Festival was delayed due to wind. California Highway Patrol reported a palm tree down in the road, as well as power lines down and power outages in the Coachella Valley.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts of 69 mph were reported at Whitewater RAWS, with a gust of 59 mph also reported in Sky Valley between 0650 and 0850 PST. Indian Canyon Drive was closed to all traffic for 7 hours between Garnett Ave. and West Tramview Rd. due to high winds and blowing sand. High winds caused a tractor-trailer to flip on its side at San Rafael Drive and Indian Canyon Drive. All restaurants and gas stations were closed at Indian Canyon Drive and I-10 on the 12th. High winds downed 2 power poles in North Palm Springs. Numerous power outages occured in the vicinity of Indian Canyon.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak trough from the Pacific Northwest progressed through Southern California on the 11th and 12th, bringing gusty winds to the Coachella Valley, San Bernardino County Mountains, and San Diego County Deserts. Palm Springs Airport diverted 4 planes early on the 12th due to wind shear on final approach. The opening of the Coachella Festival was delayed due to wind. California Highway Patrol reported a palm tree down in the road, as well as power lines down and power outages in the Coachella Valley.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts were over 50 mph from 0800 to 2300 PST, with a peak wind gust of 67 mph at Whitewater RAWS at 1600 PST. Surrounding areas had peak wind gusts of around 40 mph. A big rig was blown over at Palm Dr. and Varner Rd. High winds blew a trailer off of a vehicle on Highway 111.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A trough of low pressure from the Pacific Northwest brought strong onshore winds to Southern California on the 16th and 17th. Workers at the Coachella Valley Festival were evacuated for a period of time due to high winds and blowing sand. A tractor-trailer flipped in Palm Springs.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts over 45 mph impacted the Coachella Mesonet from 1200 to 2300 PST, with a peak wind gust of 58 mph at 1800 PST. Visibility was down to 1/2 mile in some parts of the Coachella Valley. Workers at the Coachella Valley Festival were evacuated on the evening of the 16th due to high winds and blowing sand.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A trough of low pressure from the Pacific Northwest brought strong onshore winds to Southern California on the 16th and 17th. Workers at the Coachella Valley Festival were evacuated for a period of time due to high winds and blowing sand. A tractor-trailer flipped in Palm Springs.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Whitewater RAWS reported a maximum sustained wind of 49 mph at 1150 PST on the 19th. The maximum gust in that time period was 63 mph. California Highway Patrol reported issues using medical aircraft to respond to an auto accident in the area.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A trough of low pressure from the Pacific Northwest brought gusty onshore winds to Southern California on the 18th and 19th. The Coachella Fesitval campsite delayed opening from the 19th to the early morning hours on the 20th due to high winds and blowing sand.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts for Palm Springs Airport were over 40 mph from 1800 to 2000 PST, with a peak gust of 56 mph and a sustained wind of 39 mph at 1815 PST. Surrounding areas reported wind gusts of around 30 mph. The campsite at the Coachella Valley Festival delayed opening until the 20th at 0200 PST due to high winds and blowing sand, leaving tourists stranded until the campsite opened.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A trough of low pressure from the Pacific Northwest brought gusty onshore winds to Southern California on the 18th and 19th. The Coachella Fesitval campsite delayed opening from the 19th to the early morning hours on the 20th due to high winds and blowing sand.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Patterson Fire ignited around 1 pm PST on May 17th. Six homes were evacuated around 1500 PST on Hidden Falls Road and Vista Road, and one unoccupied structure was destroyed in the fire. The fire rapidly grew to approximately 1,200 acres by 1830 PST on the 17th. Evacuations were lifted around 2100 PST on the 17th. The fire was contained around 1800 PST on May 18th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wildfire ignited a few miles south of Winchester in Riverside County on May 17th. Lower relative humidity and wind speeds between 15-20 mph helped exasperate the fire. Evacuations were put in place for six homes near the fire, and one structure was destroyed.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High pressure aloft brought in dry conditions and extreme temperatures to the Coachella Valley on June 3-5. Temperatures reached 113 in Palm Springs and Thermal on the 3rd and 4th, and decreased to 104 on the 5th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure aloft brought in dry and hot conditions to the deserts from June 3rd through 5th. Extreme heat was observed in the Coachella Valley and San Diego County Deserts, and one person died from a heat-related illness.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Coachella Valley experienced extreme high temperatures due to a high pressure aloft bringing dry and warm conditions to the region. Palm Springs recorded a temperature of 112 on June 13 and 14. Overnight lows were in the mid-80s in the Coachella Valley.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure aloft brought dry conditions and extreme temperatures to the Coachella Valley and San Diego County Deserts. Temperatures reached 112 in Palm Springs and 113 in Ocotillo Wells on June 13.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Extreme temperatures were recorded in the Coachella Valley on June 21 and 22 as high pressure aloft brought dry and hot temperatures into the region. On June 22, Palm Springs recorded a high temperature of 116 and Thermal recorded a high temperature of 114.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A heatwave impacted the Coachella Valley and San Diego County deserts on June 21-22 due to high pressure aloft bringing in dry and hot conditions to those areas. Temperatures in the Coachella Valley reached between 114 and 116 and temperatures in the San Diego County Deserts reached 114-115 on June 22. One person died in Ocotillo Wells Recreational State Park due to heat.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Martinez Fire broke out around 1400 PST on June 23rd. Dry conditions and temperatures in the 120s helped exasperate the fire. Seven homes were destroyed. Approximately 30 tribal members were displaced from their homes and lost nearly all of their possessions. Three firefighters suffered minor injuries in the blaze.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A fire broke out at the Torres Martinez Desert Cahuilla Reservation in the Coachella Valley on June 23rd. Seven homes were destroyed and the fire affected 30 tribal members in total. Members were displaced from their homes and lost all of their possessions.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Even the desert was hot on July 6, 120F reported at Thermal and 119F at Palm Springs. These were shy of the 123-124F all-time highs. Palm Springs managed to reach 115F the following day.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong broad upper level high pressure centered over Nevada and unusual weak offshore flow in July brought extreme hot temperatures and dry conditions to Southern California from July 6th through 8th. Inland Orange County, San Diego Valleys, Inland Empire and the deserts experienced the most extreme temperatures. July 6th was the hottest day during this event, with Thermal and Chino reaching 120 degrees, and San Bernardino and Riverside Airport reaching 118 degrees. July 7th and 8th remained quite hot -- only a few degrees cooler than July 6th. Heat began to subside significantly on July 9th.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: On July 6, temperature at Chino ASOS reached 120F. This is the highest recorded reading for this location and possibly for an ASOS not in the desert. Ontario ASOS reached 117F, the prior highest reading was 114F. Riverside Airport hit 118F and Lake Elsinore reach 119F. On Saturday July 7, the temperatures cooled to 114 at Chino, 113 at Riverside and 112 at Ontario.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong broad upper level high pressure centered over Nevada and unusual weak offshore flow in July brought extreme hot temperatures and dry conditions to Southern California from July 6th through 8th. Inland Orange County, San Diego Valleys, Inland Empire and the deserts experienced the most extreme temperatures. July 6th was the hottest day during this event, with Thermal and Chino reaching 120 degrees, and San Bernardino and Riverside Airport reaching 118 degrees. July 7th and 8th remained quite hot -- only a few degrees cooler than July 6th. Heat began to subside significantly on July 9th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large thunderstorm cell progressed south off of the San Gorgonio Mountain into Banning on July 7th around 1100 PST.  It brought strong winds to the Banning area, in particular, Sylvan Park. Numerous trees were damaged from winds in the park. After a storm survey, the winds in Sylvan Park were estimated to be 56 knots from the thunderstorm.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Monsoonal moisture and atmospheric instability resulted in widespread thunderstorm activity in Riverside and San Bernardino counties on July 7th. A large thunderstorm from the San Bernardino Mountains moved south into Banning and brought gusty winds to the area. Sylvan Park was the hardest hit, where numerous trees were damaged. Winds were estimated to be 56 knots.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: An intense line of thunderstorms across Arizona pushed to the west- northwest into Southern California around 0000 PST on July 9th. By 0100 PST, the thunderstorms began to collapse. The outflow boundary produced a gust front, which brought some gusty winds and kicked up a good bit of dust and dirt. The gust front pushed into the Coachella Valley around 0130-0200 PST and greatly reduced visibility through 15z. Visibility of �� of a mile was reported in Thermal. The intense winds downs a power pole and line onto a house, which caused it to catch fire. A wind gust of 40 knots was reported in Indio. Haze and dust were present in the Coachella Valley for a few hours in the morning of July 9th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms from Arizona pushed into Southern California early on July 9th. The thunderstorm collapsed and produced a gust front, which brought strong winds into the Coachella Valley. These winds kicked up a significant amount of dust, reducing visibility to as low as 3/4 of a mile. The intense winds knocked over a power pole, and resulted in a house fire.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mesonet station (f2736) reported a 24-hour rainfall total of 1.56 inches.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Increased monsoonal moisture in Southern California resulted in thunderstorms, heavy rain, and debris flows across the region, particularly in the mountain areas.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The ASOS station at Palm Springs Airport recorded a 54 knot thunderstorm wind gust around 1753 PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Increased monsoonal moisture in Southern California resulted in numerous thunderstorms across the region. Flash flooding, debris flows, and lightning reported in the San Bernardino Mountains. San Diego and Riverside counties saw flash flooding too along with thunderstorm winds that caused damage. Various roads were closed through the afternoon and evening due to flooding and debris flows.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: California Highway Patrol reported that rocks and debris were blocking the roadway at Dillon Road and Bubbling Wells Road.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Increased monsoonal moisture in Southern California resulted in numerous thunderstorms across the region. Flash flooding, debris flows, and lightning reported in the San Bernardino Mountains. San Diego and Riverside counties saw flash flooding too along with thunderstorm winds that caused damage. Various roads were closed through the afternoon and evening due to flooding and debris flows.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Palm Springs ASOS reported 1.08 inches of rain from 1700 PST to 1900 PST on July 11th. This was a daily record amount of rainfall for that location.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Increased monsoonal moisture in Southern California resulted in numerous thunderstorms across the region. Flash flooding, debris flows, and lightning reported in the San Bernardino Mountains. San Diego and Riverside counties saw flash flooding too along with thunderstorm winds that caused damage. Various roads were closed through the afternoon and evening due to flooding and debris flows.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Martinez Fire broke out around 1400 PST on July 23rd. Dry conditions and temperatures in the 120s helped exasperate the fire. Seven homes were destroyed. Approximately 30 tribal members were displaced from their homes and lost nearly all of their possessions. Three firefighters suffered minor injuries in the blaze.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Martinez Fire broke out on the Torres Martinez Reservation in Mecca around 1400 PST on July 23rd. Seven homes were destroyed and 30 tribal members were displaced. Three firefighters suffered minor injuries.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Cranston Fire started on 7/25 around 1100 PST in the Riverside County Mountains. By 1700 PST on 7/25, the fire had rapidly grown to 1,200 acres. In total, the Cranston Fire burned 13,000 acres, resulted in over 500 people being evacuated, and scorched 5 structures. The cause of the fire was determined to be arson. The Cranston Fire was fully contained on 8/13.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Cranston Fire started around 1100 PST on 7/25 in the Riverside County Mountains near the town of Idyllwild. Nearby communities in Idyllwild, Mountain Center and Fern Valley were evacuated. In total, the fire scorched 13,000 acres, 5 structures and resulted in many road closures. The fire was fully contained on August 13.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Cranston Fire started on July 25th and continued to burn through August 13th when it was fully extinguished. It started on 7/25 around 1100 PST in the Riverside County Mountains. By 1700 PST on 7/25, the fire had rapidly grown to 1,200 acres. In total, the Cranston Fire burned 13,000 acres, resulted in over 500 people being evacuated, and scorched 5 structures. The cause of the fire was determined to be arson.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Cranston Fire began in late July and continued to actively burn through August 13th, 2018. It started around 1100 PST on 7/25 in the Riverside County Mountains near the town of Idyllwild. Nearby communities in Idyllwild, Mountain Center and Fern Valley were evacuated. In total, the fire scorched 13,000 acres, 5 structures and resulted in many road closures.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Inland Empire experienced temperatures in excess of 100 degrees on August 6th and 7th. Most areas in the Inland Empire experienced temperatures of 100-105 degrees, with the highest values observed in San Bernardino (108 degrees) and Lake Elsinore (111 degrees). The heat began to subside slightly on the 8th, with warm conditions continuing throughout the week.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong high pressure positioned over the Great Basin ushered in excessive temperatures into Southern California August 6-9. The desert areas and the Inland Empire experienced the hottest temperatures in this event. The inland areas experienced the brunt of the heat on August 6th-8th, with temperatures beginning to subside on August 9th. The coastal areas experienced their hottest temperatures on August 9th. The heat slowly began subsiding in all areas on August 10th, but remained quite hot throughout the week. Of significance, the Sea Surface Temperatures at La Jolla reached an all-time record high of 79.5F and several buoys reported 78-79F, peaking on August 9th. This is about 10 degrees above normal. The warm SST in July and August resulted in muggy conditions with dewpoints 70 to 72F reported for a few weeks at coastal observations including SAN. The minimum temperature did not drop below 70F at SAN for 36 consecutive days. Many days exceed 85F. August 2018 was the hottest on record for SAN (average temperature) and July and August combined was #2.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Coachella Valley experienced the most extreme temperatures in Southern California during this heat event. Thermal hit 117 degrees and Palm Springs reach 115 degrees on August 6th. Similar temperatures were observed on August 7th as well. Heat began to subside on Thursday, August 9th, but it remained quite warm in the Coachella Valley through the entire week.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong high pressure positioned over the Great Basin ushered in excessive temperatures into Southern California August 6-9. The desert areas and the Inland Empire experienced the hottest temperatures in this event. The inland areas experienced the brunt of the heat on August 6th-8th, with temperatures beginning to subside on August 9th. The coastal areas experienced their hottest temperatures on August 9th. The heat slowly began subsiding in all areas on August 10th, but remained quite hot throughout the week. Of significance, the Sea Surface Temperatures at La Jolla reached an all-time record high of 79.5F and several buoys reported 78-79F, peaking on August 9th. This is about 10 degrees above normal. The warm SST in July and August resulted in muggy conditions with dewpoints 70 to 72F reported for a few weeks at coastal observations including SAN. The minimum temperature did not drop below 70F at SAN for 36 consecutive days. Many days exceed 85F. August 2018 was the hottest on record for SAN (average temperature) and July and August combined was #2.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Holy Fire began in the Santa Ana Mountains around 2:15 PM PST on August 6th. The hot and dry conditions helped to exasperate the fire further. By the morning of August 7, the fire had increased in size to 4,000 acres and by August 8, it had grown to 6,200 acres. By August 9, more than 21,400 people in 7,400 residences were placed under mandatory evacuation in south Corona, Lake Elsinore, and several communities in the Santa Ana Mountains. Ortega Highway was closed for an indefinite period of time, due to fire danger between Antonio Parkway in San Juan Capistrano and Grand Avenue in the Lake Elsinore. The fire size in total ended up growing to over 23,000 acres. Eighteen structures were destroyed in Orange and Riverside Counties. No major injuries or deaths were reported. The fire was fully contained on September 13th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Holy Fire started around 2:15 PM PST on August 6th and spread rapidly through the Santa Ana Mountains. Hot temperatures and dry conditions helped exasperate the fire even further. Evacuation orders were issued for parts of Trabuco Canyon, including the entire community of Holy Jim. The fire grew in total to over 23,000 acres and was fully contained on September 13th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with gusty outflow winds affected the far eastern portion of Riverside County during the late evening hours on August 9th, including the community of Blythe. Some of the stronger storms generated gusty outflow winds that stirred up areas of dense blowing dust resulting in dust storm conditions along Interstate 10. At 2326PST the official ASOS weather station at the Blythe Airport measured a visibility of one quarter mile in dense blowing dust. A Dust Storm warning had been issued earlier for the area but it expired at 2300PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Late evening thunderstorms developed over far eastern portions of Riverside County on August 9th and some of the stronger storms produced gusty outflow winds reaching as high as 60 mph that stirred up significant amounts of blowing dust leading to dust storm conditions. The dense blowing dust affected areas along the lower Colorado River Valley including the community of Blythe. The official ASOS automatic weather station at the Blythe airport recorded a wind gust to 60 mph and also measured visibility down to one quarter of a mile at 2323PST; a Dust Storm Warning had been issued earlier for the area but the warning expired at 2300PST. Despite severely restricted visibility and hazardous driving conditions, no reports of accidents were received.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with strong outflow winds developed over far eastern Riverside County during the late evening hours on August 9th and one of the stronger storms affected areas around the community of Blythe. At 2226PST the official ASOS weather station at the Blythe airport measured a wind gust of 60 mph.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Late evening thunderstorms developed over far eastern portions of Riverside County on August 9th and some of the stronger storms produced gusty outflow winds reaching as high as 60 mph that stirred up significant amounts of blowing dust leading to dust storm conditions. The dense blowing dust affected areas along the lower Colorado River Valley including the community of Blythe. The official ASOS automatic weather station at the Blythe airport recorded a wind gust to 60 mph and also measured visibility down to one quarter of a mile at 2323PST; a Dust Storm Warning had been issued earlier for the area but the warning expired at 2300PST. Despite severely restricted visibility and hazardous driving conditions, no reports of accidents were received.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with strong and damaging outflow winds developed and moved across the community of Desert Center during the afternoon hours on August 15th. According to a trained weather spotter, at 1640PST outflow winds estimated to be as high as 75 mph downed 8 power lines and flipped over 3 mobile trailers. One of the trailers was completely demolished. The damage occurred about 5 miles to the northeast of the town of Desert Center and near the Desert Center airport. The damage was east of Highway 177 and north of Interstate 10. No injuries were reported due to the extensive damage.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Monsoon thunderstorms developed across portions of eastern Riverside county during the afternoon hours on August 15th; some of the stronger storms generated gusty and damaging outflow winds that affected areas around the community of Desert Center. A trained spotter indicated that gusty winds estimated to be in excess of 70 mph downed a number of power poles and flipped 3 mobile trailers approximately 5 miles to the northeast of Desert Center and near the Desert Center airport. One of the trailers was completely destroyed. No injuries were reported as a result of the wind damage.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with locally heavy rain developed over portions of Joshua Tree National Park during the early to middle afternoon hours on August 16th. Some of the storms generated intense rain that led to episodes of flash flooding just south of the San Bernardino County line and  5 to 8 miles east of Lost Horse. According to a report from the public, at 1400PST significant flash flooding occurred near Skull Rock with water observed flowing across Park Boulevard. Shortly after that, at 1420PST, park and forest service personnel reported flash flooding as water 1 foot deep was flowing over Park Boulevard between Geology Tour Road and Sheep Pass campground. There were also numerous flows through all of the dirt roads leading to numerous washouts. Fortunately no accidents were reported as a result of the flash flooding. A Flash Flood Warning was issued for the area at 1254PST until 1600PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Monsoon thunderstorms with locally heavy rain developed over portions of Joshua Tree National Park during the middle of the afternoon on August 16th. The stronger storms generated intense rainfall that was sufficient to cause episodes of flash flooding within the park. Some of the most significant flash flooding occurred about 5 miles of Lost Horse and just south of the Riverside - San Bernardino county line. Park and forest service personnel reported flash flooding with water running 1 foot deep over Park Boulevard between Geology Tour Road and Sheep Pass Campground. There were numerous flows through various dirt roads resulting in washouts. Significant flooding also occurred near Skull Rock with water flowing over Park Boulevard. At 1530PST there was a public report of flash flooding about 8 miles north of the Cottonwood Visitors Center; flooding was occurring over Pinto Basin Road between mile markers 10 and 20. Flash Flood Warnings were issued as a result of the significant flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Public reports of a landspout tornado northwest of Anza, CA. No injuries or damages were reported.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Monsoonal moisture moved into Southern California on August 15th and resulted in numerous showers and thunderstorms across the region. Heavy rain fell in the San Diego County Mountains on August 15th, and became more widespread on August 16th and 17th. Mount Laguna picked up 3.20 inches of rainfall on August 17th. Numerous areas of flash flooding and debris flows were reported throughout Southern California, particularly in the Riverside and San Bernardino County mountain areas. A landspout tornado was reported in the Anza Valley associated with a severe thunderstorm. No injuries or major damages were reported.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: CHP reported that Brookside Avenue and Highland Springs Avenue was flooded out on both sides of the road from the heavy rain.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Monsoonal moisture moved into Southern California on August 15th and resulted in numerous showers and thunderstorms across the region. Heavy rain fell in the San Diego County Mountains on August 15th, and became more widespread on August 16th and 17th. Mount Laguna picked up 3.20 inches of rainfall on August 17th. Numerous areas of flash flooding and debris flows were reported throughout Southern California, particularly in the Riverside and San Bernardino County mountain areas. A landspout tornado was reported in the Anza Valley associated with a severe thunderstorm. No injuries or major damages were reported.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with locally heavy rain developed across portions of Joshua Tree National Park during the afternoon hours on August 16th; some of the stronger storms produced intense rain that led to an episode of flash flooding in the park. According to a report from the public, flash flooding was observed about 8 miles north of the Cottonwood Visitor's Center and along Pinto Basin Road. The flooding was between mile markers 10 and 20; most of the flows going across the road were spaced out between one and one and one half miles. The report indicated that the flooding occurred at about 1530PST. A Flash Flood Warning was issued for the area at 1504PST and was in effect through 1800MST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Monsoon thunderstorms with locally heavy rain developed over portions of Joshua Tree National Park during the middle of the afternoon on August 16th. The stronger storms generated intense rainfall that was sufficient to cause episodes of flash flooding within the park. Some of the most significant flash flooding occurred about 5 miles of Lost Horse and just south of the Riverside - San Bernardino county line. Park and forest service personnel reported flash flooding with water running 1 foot deep over Park Boulevard between Geology Tour Road and Sheep Pass Campground. There were numerous flows through various dirt roads resulting in washouts. Significant flooding also occurred near Skull Rock with water flowing over Park Boulevard. At 1530PST there was a public report of flash flooding about 8 miles north of the Cottonwood Visitors Center; flooding was occurring over Pinto Basin Road between mile markers 10 and 20. Flash Flood Warnings were issued as a result of the significant flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: California Department of Transportation reported that there were dozens of small debris flows in and around the Cranston Fire burn scar on August 15th  but highway 74 was proactively closed based on NWS warnings. On August 17th, there was a large debris flow up to 5 feet deep in the Lake Hemet Campground area from Hurkey Creek. Again highway 74 was closed about 2 hours in advanced based on NWS briefings and the actual Flash Flood Warning.  Very large boulders were reported to have traveled downstream on the upper Hurkey Creek near Fleming Ranch. Evacuations were in order at Hurkey Creek Campground and Sheriff was on site monitoring the potential based on NWS briefings. Video of the debris flow was captured. A storm survey was conducted by NWS following the debris flow. No injuries or major damages reported from this event. Rain gauges in the area reported 1-1.5 inches of rainfall near the Cranston Fire burn scar. Evacuations of the small communities near the Cranston Fire burn scar were put into place on August 15th in anticipation of the heavy rainfall and potential for flash flooding and debris flows.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Monsoonal moisture moved into Southern California on August 15th and resulted in numerous showers and thunderstorms across the region. Heavy rain fell in the San Diego County Mountains on August 15th, and became more widespread on August 16th and 17th. Mount Laguna picked up 3.20 inches of rainfall on August 17th. Numerous areas of flash flooding and debris flows were reported throughout Southern California, particularly in the Riverside and San Bernardino County mountain areas. A landspout tornado was reported in the Anza Valley associated with a severe thunderstorm. No injuries or major damages were reported.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: CHP reported boulders across the roadway on Highway 74 in Pinyon Pines near the fire station. No injuries or damages were reported.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Monsoonal moisture moved into Southern California on August 15th and resulted in numerous showers and thunderstorms across the region. Heavy rain fell in the San Diego County Mountains on August 15th, and became more widespread on August 16th and 17th. Mount Laguna picked up 3.20 inches of rainfall on August 17th. Numerous areas of flash flooding and debris flows were reported throughout Southern California, particularly in the Riverside and San Bernardino County mountain areas. A landspout tornado was reported in the Anza Valley associated with a severe thunderstorm. No injuries or major damages were reported.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sheriff reported that a major debris flow occurred on Highway 74 near the Cranston Fire  burn scar. No injuries or damages were reported.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Monsoonal moisture moved into Southern California on August 15th and resulted in numerous showers and thunderstorms across the region. Heavy rain fell in the San Diego County Mountains on August 15th, and became more widespread on August 16th and 17th. Mount Laguna picked up 3.20 inches of rainfall on August 17th. Numerous areas of flash flooding and debris flows were reported throughout Southern California, particularly in the Riverside and San Bernardino County mountain areas. A landspout tornado was reported in the Anza Valley associated with a severe thunderstorm. No injuries or major damages were reported.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A thunderstorms produced radar estimated 2 to 4 inches of rain in Box Canyon near I-10 within Box Canyon. The runoff destroyed a dike operated by Coachella Valley Water District. The moisture was associated with pre Tropical Cyclone Rosa. The thunderstorm produced prolific lightning in the area. Box Canyon had a flash flood which drains from the little San Bernardino mountains. The water eventually drains into the Salton Sea. A vehicle travelling on Box Canyon road was swept away in the flash flood and the driver drowned (within PHX area of responsibility).
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moisture from Tropical Storm Rosa advanced into Southern California on September 30th and brought rain and thunderstorms to the region. The areas that experienced significant rainfall on the 30th were the San Bernardino Mountains and the Coachella Valley. One person was reported missing in the Coachella Valley during the same time period where heavy rainfall of 1.5-3.5 inches in 2 hours occurred.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy rain developed across portions of eastern Riverside County during the evening hours on September 30th. The stronger storms produced intense rain that led to flash flooding to the southwest of Joshua Tree National Park and to the north of the Salton Sea. At 1925PST the California Highway Patrol reported that Box Canyon Road was closed at the Mecca Copia Trail due to flash flooding. Significant impacts were reported to have occurred further downstream. Major damage was reportedly done to the Box Canyon Road forcing the road to be closed for days. It was also reported that a man was swept to his death driving along Box Canyon Road between Interstate 10 and Highway 111.  He was returning from a camping trip in Joshua Tree National Park. His damaged car was found by the road later the next day with no trace of the man to be found. A Flash Flood Warning was issued for the area at 1909MST and it remained in effect until 2215MST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Deep tropical moisture started to spread north and into far southeast California during the day on September 30th; the moisture spread into the area ahead of Hurricane Rosa and led to the development of isolated thunderstorms. Due to the tropical nature of the moisture, the storms that developed produced very heavy rain which led to an episode of flash flooding in eastern Riverside County, to the southwest of Joshua Tree National Park and just north of the Salton Sea. At 1925PST, the California Highway Patrol indicated that Box Canyon Road was closed at Mecca Copia Trail due to flash flooding. The patrol indicated that there were significant flooding issues further downstream with major damage done to Box Canyon Road. It was also reported that a man was swept off of Box Canyon Road and to his death due to flash flooding of a large wash running across the road, between Interstate 10 and Highway 111.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain from Tropical Storm Sergio resulted in flash flooding in the Coachella Valley. The runoff destroyed a dike operated by the Coachella Valley Water District for a second time.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moisture from Tropical Storm Sergio made its way into Southern California on October 12th and 13th, bringing heavy rain to the region. The Riverside County mountains and the Coachella Valley received the most precipitation in the region, with some areas exceeding 1 inch of rainfall. The Coachella Valley Water District dyke was blown out and resulted in damage to the infrastructure.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 12 hour rainfall report from the public of 0.72 inches of rainfall in Palm Desert.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moisture from Tropical Storm Sergio advanced into the Coachella Valley late on October 12th and resulted in widespread thunderstorms with heavy rain into the morning of October 13th, flash flooding, and hail. Many flash floods were reported across the area, as well as quarter-sized hail in Indio.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Broadcast media reported quarter sized (1 inch) hail in Indio. No damages or injuries were reported.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moisture from Tropical Storm Sergio advanced into the Coachella Valley late on October 12th and resulted in widespread thunderstorms with heavy rain into the morning of October 13th, flash flooding, and hail. Many flash floods were reported across the area, as well as quarter-sized hail in Indio.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: CalTrans reported flash flooding on Interstate-10. The flooding was 1.5 ft deep and 12 ft wide over the interstate.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moisture from Tropical Storm Sergio advanced into the Coachella Valley late on October 12th and resulted in widespread thunderstorms with heavy rain into the morning of October 13th, flash flooding, and hail. Many flash floods were reported across the area, as well as quarter-sized hail in Indio.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A vigorous upper level low pressure system moved into eastern Riverside County shortly after midnight and triggered the development of numerous showers with embedded thunderstorms. Some of the stronger storms generated very heavy rain, with peak rain rates in excess of 2 inches per hour. The intense rain led to flash flooding just north of the Salton Sea and near the Salton Sea State Recreation Area. According to local law enforcement, at 0005PST flash flooding was observed at State Route 111 and Bay Drive. No accidents were reported due to the flash flooding. A Flash Flood Warning was in effect at the time of the flooding.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level low pressure system moved into far southeast California during the early morning hours on October 13th and triggered the development of widespread showers and thunderstorms. Many of the stronger thunderstorms produced intense and very heavy rain that led to episodes of flash flooding across portions of eastern Riverside County.  Park and Forest Service personnel reported many paved roads in Joshua Tree National Park flooded and washed out starting shortly after midnight. Flash flooding was also observed just north of the Salton Sea, with roadway flooding near the Salton Sea State Recreation Area. In addition, local law enforcement reported flash flooding near Interstate 10 at about 0230 PST, about 10 miles east of Desert Center. Multiple Flash Flood Warnings were issued for the area during the early morning hours. Fortunately, no accidents or injuries were reported due to flash flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level low pressure system moved east and into Joshua Tree National Park around Midnight on October 12 and triggered the development of widespread showers along with embedded thunderstorms. Some of the stronger storms generated intense rain with peak rain rates over 2 inches per hour. The heavy rain led to episodes of flash flooding across Joshua Tree National Park during the very early morning hours on October 13. According to the Park and Forest Service, at 0030PST flash flooding caused most of the paved roads, including Pinto Basin Road and Highway 62 near the town of Joshua Tree, to become closed. Pretty much all of the dirt roads around Joshua Tree National Park were also closed. Flash Flood Warnings were issued for the park due to the heavy rain and flooding. Fortunately there were no reports of accidents or injuries in the park due to the flash flooding.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level low pressure system moved into far southeast California during the early morning hours on October 13th and triggered the development of widespread showers and thunderstorms. Many of the stronger thunderstorms produced intense and very heavy rain that led to episodes of flash flooding across portions of eastern Riverside County.  Park and Forest Service personnel reported many paved roads in Joshua Tree National Park flooded and washed out starting shortly after midnight. In addition, local law enforcement reported flash flooding near Interstate 10 at about 0230 PST, about 10 miles east of Desert Center. Multiple Flash Flood Warnings were issued for the area during the early morning hours. Fortunately, no accidents or injuries were reported due to flash flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: CHP reported flash flooding at Varner Drive and Date Palm Drive and requested that the road be closed to traffic.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: CalTrans reported Dillion Road at East Deception Road flooded out around 0030 PST on October 13th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: CalTrans reported road flooded at Monterey Ave and Ramon Road in Thousand Palms. Vehicles were unable to get through.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level low pressure system moved east and across eastern Riverside County during the early morning hours on October 7th. The low triggered the development of numerous showers and embedded thunderstorms, and some of the stronger storms generated intense rain with peak rain rates in excess of 2 inches per hour. The heavy rain led to episodes of flash flooding, including one along Interstate 10. According to local law enforcement, at 0233PST flash flooding occurred on East Corn Springs  Road near Interstate 10. Fortunately there were no accidents or injuries due to the flooded road. A Flash Flood Warning was in effect at the time of the flooding.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level low pressure system moved into far southeast California during the early morning hours on October 13th and triggered the development of widespread showers and thunderstorms. CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ontario Airport ASOS reported a 52 knot wind gust between 0900 and 1000 PST on October 15th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong Santa Ana Wind event impacted Southern California on October 15th. Multiple mesonet sites reported winds in excess of 58 mph, with the highest wind gust of 82 mph at Fremont Canyon. Orange County reported over 200 downed trees. There was one fatality from a fallen tree crushing a vehicle.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: CalState San Bernardino Mesonet reported a wind gust of 56 knots between 1200 and 1300 PST on November 8th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Surface high pressure centered over Idaho and Nevada brought strong offshore winds to Southern California from November 8th through 13th. The highest wind gust from the event was 85 mph at Sill Hill on November 12th. The air mass on November 8-10th was extremely dry with dewpoints observed at -25 to -40F between 6000 and 9000 feet (matched NKX sounding data). Fuel moisture measured by the USFS was at historical lows (100 and 1000 hour). Power was cut from many wildfire prone communities in anticipation of high winds. Some power lines were knocked over from the winds, but there were no significant fire starts. USFS reported several small wildfires during night hours but they were able to quick control the blazes before spreading.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Whitewater raws mesonet reported a peak wind gust of 52 knots between 0700 and 0800 PST on November 30th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system brought wind, snow, heavy rain, and some debris flows to Southern California from November 29th through 30th. Strong wind associated with the frontal boundary made its way through Southern California on the 29th, with heavy rain behind it. These rains resulted in numerous flash floods and debris flows, closing roadways and impacting traffic. A few inches of snow fell in the San Bernardino Mountains on November 30th. Fawnskin reported 3 inches, Green Valley Lake reported 4 inches, and Big Bear Resort reported 4-8 inches.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Media reported highway 60 (Pomona Ave.) at Etiwanda Ave. was flooded due to heavy rain with accidents reported in the area.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mud and debris flowed right next to Rice Canyon Elementary School on December 6th due to heavy rain in the burn scar area.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A moisture plume with a weak atmospheric river arrived on December 5th and brought rain to the region. On December 6th, a strong closed upper level low pressure brought an unstable air mass into Southern California with showers and thunderstorms, especially Orange and San Diego Counties. Rainfall of 1 inch per hour amounts occurred in Costa Mesa and downtown San Diego as well as adjacent cities. The main storm system on December 6th brought widespread rain to the entire region. All mountains and the coast and valleys areas received 1-3 inches and some spots receiving over 4 of rainfall over higher terrain. The most significant mud and debris flows occurred at recent Holy burn scar areas, and many reports of flash flooding across the region. Another strong cold front brought widespread rain on Christmas Day though the impacts were minimal. Snow fell as low as 4000 feet with mountains receiving 1 to 4 inches of snow including the San Diego mountains. Burns Canyon in the high deserts of San Bernardino County had a wind gust to 70 mph.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Pacific Coast Highway (Route 1) was closed between 3rd and 9th street in South Laguna Beach due to flash flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mud, water and debris impacted Grand Ave near Lakeshore Drive in Lake Elsinore due to heavy rain in the Holy fire burn area around 1400 PST on December 6th. Some areas of Grand Ave. reported mud 1 to 3 feet deep covering streets and yards.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Notable heavy rainfall rates at the Holy Fire burn scar. Coldwater Canyon received 0.35 of rainfall in 30 minutes. McVicker Canyon received 0.35 in 15 minutes. USGS 30-minute burn scar rainfall thresholds were exceeded in 60 canyons, and the 1-hour thresholds were exceeded in 5 canyons.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: White Water RAWS recorded a peak wind gust of 50 knots between 2250 and 2350 on December 24th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level trough from the northwest moved into Southern California on December 24th and 25th, bringing heavy rain, snow above 4000 ft and high winds. Coastal areas received 0.25-0.50 of rain, valley areas received up to an inch of rain, and mountain areas up to 1.50 of rain. Winds gusted to 50-70 mph in the mountains and deserts.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: White Water RAWS reported a peak wind gust of 54 knots between 2150 and 2250 PST on December 30th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold inside slider moved into Southern California on New Year's Eve, bringing rain and snow to the region. San Diego County received most of the precipitation from this event. San Diego coastal areas received 0.25-0.50, valley and mountain areas received 0.50-1.0. The mountain areas of San Diego County received 1-2 inches of snow above 4000 ft. High winds were also observed during this event. Gusts of 50-60 mph were recorded in the Riverside and San Diego County Mountains.
